page.title: 02FARMING IN MARSHFIELD
page.content: The area is mainly grassland with stone walls, hedges and some woodland. The terrain has south facing valleys and is on the edge of the Cotswold brash. The land is chiefly grazed by cattle to fatten for meat. Some sheep are kept but the flocks average under a hundred rather than more. Dipping has been compulsory during summer and autumn to check sheep-scab. No case has been reported in Marshfield. The arable land grows winter crops of wheat, barley and oats; also spring sown crops. A small acreage is taken by potatoes and swedes. Oilseed rape was grown this year. The farms are owner-occupied in this block, apart from seventy acres or so. The farms are generally run by the families concerned, very little outside labour being employed. (Continued)
